body:
ðŸ‘ðŸ» - Same issue with .CSV files.  Workaround:  use Streamlit 1.44.1 instead.  Here's the full bug report, steps to recreate, and comparison between working/non-working deployments of the same software using different versions of Streamlit (1.44.1 vs 1.45.0).

https://discuss.streamlit.io/t/bug-in-st-file-uploader-type-csv-for-streamlit-version-1-45-0/111379/2

Thanks in advance!
@pr3d4t0r Are you on windows by chance? I just tried reproducing this issue, and I do not see anything.
One other question for @pr3d4t0r and @JKen0 If you modify "txt" to ".txt" does it work? We made some changes to the enforcement and it might have introduced the error.

> [@pr3d4t0r](https://github.com/pr3d4t0r) Are you on windows by chance? I just tried reproducing this issue, and I do not see anything.

Howdy!

Not on Windows, and this is a Python library issue.  Aside from the environments I listed in the Streamlit.io discussion board, here's the OS information:

- Ubuntu Desktop 24.04 LTS with Firefox 138.0.1
- macOS Sequoia 15.4.1 with:
  - Firefox 138.0.1
  - LibreWolf 138.0.1
  - Brave 1.78.94
  - Safari 18.4
 
The issue is reproducible in macOS and Streamlit.app / Community cloud:

  a. FAILS: https://ssscore-bert.streamlit.app/ - Uses Streamlit 1.45.0
  b. WORKS: https://ssscore.streamlit.app/ - Uses Streamlit 1.44.1

The evidence points at an issue with the Streamlit 1.45.0 build.  The release notes indicate that someone updated `st.file_uploader()` for this release.

For full details on how to reproduce, see my ticket in the Streamlit forums:  https://discuss.streamlit.io/t/bug-in-st-file-uploader-type-csv-for-streamlit-version-1-45-0/111379

Take care and cheers!

pr3d

repository.name: SSScoring
repository.description: Speed Skydiving Scoring - the ultimate speed skydiving scoring and training API

body: This is very helpful. We did in fact that we introduced something related that probably is the culprit. However, I just tried it on my computer, and I get a different error showing the upload is succeeding. Since I cannot reproduce it, I will work on creating a custom wheel file that will log some extra information. I wonder if there's an invisible character which is causing issues. When it's ready, I'll ask that you test it and let me know if there's anything interesting in the logs.

Excelent, thanks.  Please let me know how I can help.  In the meantime, you can use one of the unit test resources to validate that everything loads and etc.  This is the basic file I used for every test in this bug report (here and in Streamlit.io forums):

Test CSV: https://raw.githubusercontent.com/pr3d4t0r/SSScoring/refs/heads/master/resources/test-tracks/FS1/test-data-00.CSV

That file is the first "valid file" for the first "valid unit test" I've done with SSScoring all the way back to when it was Lucyfer-only, so 100% sure that the file will behave as expected.

Please let me know if there's anything you'd like me to do at my end.  Cheers!

It is uppercase extensions that appear to cause the issue. It can be reproduced with just this code:
```python
st.file_uploader("Upload", type="TXT")
```
You can upload a file named `test.txt`, but trying to upload `test.TXT` will raise:
```
streamlit.errors.StreamlitAPIException: Invalid file extension: .txt. Allowed: ['.txt']
```
Note that the `type` parameter seems to be case-insensitive (`type="txt"` behaves the same), but the case in the file name matters.

Tested locally (arch, python 3.13) and streamlit cloud (python 3.12)

issue.title: Ensure filename extension check is normalized

repository.name: streamlit
repository.description: Streamlit â€” A faster way to build and share data apps.

issue.body:
## Describe your changes

We have a bug where the filename has an uppercase extension that did not pass the file extension enforcement and caused issues. This ensures we are checking the lowercase filename.

## GitHub Issue Link (if applicable)
closes #11259

## Testing Plan

- Python unit tests updated

---

**Contribution License Agreement**

By submitting this pull request you agree that all contributions to this project are made under the Apache 2.0 license.

body:
Ah @pr3d4t0r Ah. That's it. We don't normalize the filename in performing the check. Very easy fix. I just created a PR.

If you want to test it, [here's the wheel file](https://core-previews.s3-us-west-2.amazonaws.com/pr-11261/streamlit-1.45.0-py3-none-any.whl).

> It is uppercase extensions that appear to cause the issue. It can be reproduced with just this code:
> 
> st.file_uploader("Upload", type="TXT")
> 
> You can upload a file named `test.txt`, but trying to upload `test.TXT` will raise:
> 
> ```
> streamlit.errors.StreamlitAPIException: Invalid file extension: .txt. Allowed: ['.txt']
> ```
> 
> Note that the `type` parameter seems to be case-insensitive (`type="txt"` behaves the same), but the case in the file name matters.
> 
> Tested locally (arch, python 3.13) and streamlit cloud (python 3.12)

Thanks, good sleuthing.

I suspected something like this was the issue, that's why I defined `type=[ 'CSV', 'csv', ]` for `file_uploader()` - it has no effect.

If it helps, my use case processes files from three different models of GPS devices from at least two different vendors.  Files are stored in a case-insensitve FAT file system SD card.  The files are UTF-8 encoded, nothing fancy, comma-separated.  They are moved from the GPS device to the local file system (APFS, ext3, whatever Windows uses, etc.) and from there to the SSScore application on Streamlit.app.  I double-checked, no meta-data is added during the copy between FAT and the UNIX-like file systems.
